Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: During the first week of school, messages went out to families that some of the water fountains on their campuses had been put out of service and were being repaired because of elevated lead levels.
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: Community members, many of whom raised concerns two weeks ago, were skeptical.

Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: Teachers from Frick United Academy of Language demanded to know why, if testing took place in April, fountains weren’t shut down until August.
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: Teachers from Frick United Academy of Language demanded to know why, if testing took place in April, fountains weren’t shut down until August.

Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: Community members pointed out that other districts have lower thresholds for remediation.
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: Community members pointed out that other districts have lower thresholds for remediation.

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: The district’s safe drinking water policy states that any water sources showing lead at above 5 parts per billion must be taken offline and repaired.
Document Sources.Source Justification: The district’s safe drinking water policy states that any water sources showing lead at above 5 parts per billion must be taken offline and repaired.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “This mistake has caused families stress, anxiety and panic, further limiting our community’s trust in this district,” said Max Simmons, one of OUSD’s student directors.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Max Simmons, one of OUSD’s student directors.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “I sincerely apologize for the stress and concern this has caused our school sites, students and families. We understand the gravity of this situation and we are fully committed to taking immediate, transparent and corrective action,” she said.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: District leadership — including Superintendent Kyla Johnson-Trammell, chief systems and services officer Preston Thomas, and risk management officer Rebecca Littlejohn — committed to transparency going forward and said a personnel investigation is underway to determine how communication broke down.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “There is so much trust rebuilding that has to be done for our community. We have failed. And when I say ‘we’ I mean OUSD has failed at its most basic job of not poisoning our students,” said Stuart Loebl, a sixth-grade science teacher at Frick.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Stuart Loebl, a sixth-grade science teacher at Frick.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “Why didn’t you do your job? You knew months ago that the water was contaminated. You didn’t act, and you let those kids come back to school and drink poisoned water,” said Marina Muñoz, a parent at Madison Park Academy and an organizer with Communities for a Better Environment.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Marina Muñoz, a parent at Madison Park Academy and an organizer with Communities for a Better Environment.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “This is not new to Oakland, but it is something that we need to tackle as an entire city, and we need to have community partners, philanthropic partners, as well as our county and state folks to support us in dealing with this issue,” she said.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Director Valarie Bachelor, the chair of OUSD’s facilities committee, said lead abatement will continue to be a topic at every facilities meeting until the issue is resolved.

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: Alameda County recommends that any families who were notified that their schools had elevated lead levels should get their child a blood lead test.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: Alameda County recommends that any families who were notified that their schools had elevated lead levels should get their child a blood lead test.
